clinical_study.brief_title: Imaging Non-brain Electromagnetic Activity in Healthy Adults Using MEG
clinical_study.official_title: Imaging Non-brain Electromagnetic Activity in Healthy Adults Using MEG

lead_sponsor.agency: New York University School of Medicine

clinical_study.source: New York University School of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: The primary purpose of this study is to determine the effectiveness of the Magnetoencephalography (MEG) instrument to record electrical activity from parts of the body other than the brain. This study will examine if electrical activity from parts of the body, other than the brain, can be imaged by the MEG instrument. Finding will contribute to studies of pain, since abnormal electrical activity in skeletal muscle is the basis of pain, which can be severe, yet there is no non-invasive way to image this abnormal activity. This is particularly relevant to deep muscle pain and back pain.

arm_group.description: Magnetic fields will be recorded using a 275-channel whole-head MEG system

intervention.description: "Whole-Cortex MEG System" non- invasively measures the magnetoencephalographic (MEG) signals (and, optionally, electroencephalographic EEG signals) produced by electrically active tissue of the brain. These signals are recorded by a computerized data acquisition system, displayed, and may then be interpreted by trained physicians to help localize these active areas. The location may then be correlated with anatomical information of the brain. MEG is routinely used to identify the locations of visual, auditory, somatosensory, and motor cortex in the brain.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy adults who are willing and able to provide informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subjects with characteristics incompatible with MEG recordings as listed on the MEG Safety checklist (Appendix A),
- Involuntary, uncontrolled tremor,
- chronic pain.
- pregnant women (based on self-report).
